subject: Update manage-lvm role to v0.1.4
messages:
[{'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2018-12-05 15:31:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2018-12-05 15:31:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Do not merge until v0.1.4 has been published on Galaxy.'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2018-12-05 15:40:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As pointed out by ktibi on IRC, this may break existing kayobe-config repositories if they override storage_lvm_group_data. We'll need a release note."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-07 10:09:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> As pointed out by ktibi on IRC, this may break existing
 > kayobe-config repositories if they override storage_lvm_group_data.
 > We'll need a release note.

Good catch. How about we put in a check using the fail module in ansible/lvm.yml?

We were discussing how to catch things like this at the summit, and I suggested building the concept of an upgrade checker for deployment tool config, this would be a great example of where it would be useful. We could start by just tagging this task with 'upgrade-check'?"}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2018-12-20 21:58:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-21 09:05:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Thanks for adding the check!'}, {'account_id': 16984, 'date': '2019-01-04 10:51:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-01-04 11:55:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-01-04 11:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 16984, 'date': '2019-01-04 12:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

'}, {'created': '2019-01-04 11:55:22.000000000', 'message': 'Update manage-lvm role to v0.1.4

This commit updates group variables to stop transforming disk lists to

commit_message:
Update manage-lvm role to v0.1.4

This role now expects disks to be passed as a list instead of a
comma-separated string.

This commit updates group variables to stop transforming disk lists to
comma-separated strings and adds a check for users overriding LVM
variables. The playbook is also tagged as upgrade-check.

Change-Id: Ia8001c28a8be034ae79a1c584beb40bc66891db3

commit_message:
Reorganize repos into project directories

To better match how things are organized in governance, rather than a
single flat directory structure with a bazillion repos, put them into
subdirs named for their owning project.

Change-Id: I4f6fe9e9fbdc29d4e86f457a4c94f2379d4d3d3d

commit_message:
Put repo submodules below project directories

Our deliverable repos are owned by project teams. Use those to make a
directory structure that organizes the otherwise very large number of
repos.

Change-Id: Ib460ec459c168cb1dbc5ab9272459d79a1b1bc04

subject: Add placement container building
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7822, 'name': 'Chris Hoge (not involved in upstream development)', 'email': 'chris@hogepodge.com', 'username': 'hogepodge'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-11-12 10:38:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-11-12 10:39:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This adds the base so we can add it when we're ready."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-11-20 15:22:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-11-21 10:03:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck -- second recheck for timeouts. If that continues, I will work on the patch with Chris.'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2018-11-21 20:42:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The gate timeouts have been problematic. I'm not particularly happy with how the gate jobs are set up and I think we should make the majority of them non-voting since they are just doing a build and not actually testing anything. My initial thought is to make requirements voting, and maybe something like nova. The timeouts are generally because package repositories can't be reached by the host."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-11-24 11:48:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> The gate timeouts have been problematic. I'm not particularly happy
 > with how the gate jobs are set up and I think we should make the
 > majority of them non-voting since they are just doing a build and
 > not actually testing anything. My initial thought is to make
 > requirements voting, and maybe something like nova. The timeouts
 > are generally because package repositories can't be reached by the
 > host.

1) Timeouts for external repos can probably be fixed by using infra mirrors more. However, if we use them, it means we either duplicate the image building (one with infra mirrors, one without -- that one being nv): Without double image building, the published images would use infra mirrors, which is indeed undesired. Blindly trust a -nv job to do the right thing is risky, but I guess it wholly depends on core reviewers that would need to be aware of the current status.

2) If we consider NONE of the published images should be 'production', or, in other words, that all the images should be customized by consuming projects, then it would completely make sense to use 'infra only' mirrors. I'd not publish those to dockerhub in that case, but use an infra's registry.

3) For the gate jobs setup, I am happy to discuss this during next meeting.
I've checked recently at image building for OSH, and I guess experience can be shared there.

4) I would love if we decided what to actually test. There are many test frameworks that can help on the writing of those assertions.
I believe it's also better to explain what the project does, as this is basically telling what the 'contract' is."}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2018-11-28 17:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2018-12-05 20:24:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-10 09:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Chris, should we make this voting?'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-11 15:34:57.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow+1 by Chris Hoge <chris@openstack.org>
'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-11 15:35:01.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-12 09:26:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Placement builds its own container, and an analysis on how to build said container was done. It is self contained, and maybe we should not diverge from the upstream project. I will analyse this further to see if we need anything done here.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-12 16:01:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

> Placement builds its own container, and an analysis on how to build
 > said container was done. It is self contained, and maybe we should
 > not diverge from the upstream project. I will analyse this further
 > to see if we need anything done here.

While the placement container is a way, it was discussed the fact to build placement. I think we should build it, as it would look "unusual" or "weird" to not have a placement container build here.'}, {'account_id': 7822, 'date': '2018-12-20 17:28:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-04 14:12:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Placement builds its own container, and an analysis on how to build
 > said container was done. It is self contained, and maybe we should
 > not diverge from the upstream project. I will analyse this further
 > to see if we need anything done here.

The container in placedock is what might be called a "personal project" not something officially part of placement, although I'm considering moving the dockerfile into the placement, if people want it. It's nice and tiny, but it has its own unique interface to the world which may not align with what people want.'}]

commit_message:
Additional images for openshift services

This commit adds missing images for openshift service catalog and
template service broker. These two services are enabled by default by
openshift-ansible and as a result, tripleo should deploy them in its
default setting too (they were explicitly disabled in tht until now).

Change-Id: Ic358ed27d63015d297f50c10f553fc1c470ea6a5
Partial-Bug: #1806353

commit_message:
Add extracted Placement images

This change adds the now extracted Placement base and API images ahead
of the extraction of the service from Nova later in the cycle. The
existing Nova Placement API image will only be removed once both
deployments and upgrades both use these new images.

Change-Id: I5dbce7883f86ba6a92f48a398b0d0eb9b743d212

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-17 17:00:25.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent reproducer failure when there is no local ssh public key

When running reproducer on a remote machine there is no guarantee
that the current user has a public key pair created as it would be
expected to be able to use they key from ssh-agent.

New code looks for local key like before but also tries to load
the first ssh agent key if the local one is not found. Previously
the code would have failed later when trying to use pub_key
variable which was pointing to a non existing file.

commit_message:
Prevent reproducer failure when there is no local ssh public key

When running reproducer on a remote machine there is no guarantee
that the current user has a public key pair created as it would be
expected to be able to use they key from ssh-agent.

New code looks for local key like before but also tries to load
the first ssh agent key if the local one is not found. Previously
the code would have failed later when trying to use pub_key
variable which was pointing to a non existing file.

Change-Id: I440e61d235d8597f5ac3691d8d7415de7598bd9b

commit_message:
Pin bundler to 1.17.3

bundler 2.0.0 is released which needs ruby >= 2.3.0 and rubygems >= 3.0
but we are behind, so let's pin bundler to 1.17.3.

Closes-Bug: #1810401
Change-Id: Ia1190e36443e8ae24219d62771a9fd5ad46e8b25

commit_message:
Gate fix for failing at openstack-tox-docs

Zuul has been failing lately because of version conflict in
requirement for dogpile.cache package. For example in logs[1]
This PS adds requirement to fix the gate.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/75/625775/1/check/openstack-tox-docs/d9591b7/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-12-25_06_04_13_576175

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 19:24:34.000000000', 'message': 'Retry on DB deadlock when updating resource

Updating a row in the DB using UPDATE...WHERE... seems to be prone to
deadlocks. We already fixed added retries for updates of the Stack table
(bug 1578615); do the same with the Resource table.

Change-Id: I3928f1acc3c354711a27523215784a8cf8767581
Closes-Bug: #1732969
'}]
commit_message:
Retry on DB deadlock when updating resource

Updating a row in the DB using UPDATE...WHERE... seems to be prone to
deadlocks. We already fixed added retries for updates of the Stack table
(bug 1578615); do the same with the Resource table.

Change-Id: I3928f1acc3c354711a27523215784a8cf8767581
Closes-Bug: #1732969

commit_message:
cyborg/freezer-api: Remove python-astroid

Recently SUSE's astroid package was updated to 2.x which is python 3.x
only, however this package is still python 2.x. as we don't need
it we can fix this by removing the build requires

Change-Id: I0c592971471da504a1b2a5b74c613c2847b4eef4

commit_message:
Add a explicit version dep on dogpile.cache

This should solve a conflict between openstacksdk and oslo.cache. Which
shows up in the logs as:

    pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (dogpile.cache 0.7.1
    (/home/zuul/src/git.openstack.org/openstack/mistral/.tox/docs/lib/python3.5/site-packages),
    Requirement.parse('dogpile.cache<0.7.0,>=0.6.2'), {'openstacksdk'})

Closes-Bug: #1809232
Change-Id: Iff3287817469975285a1ae994d6d90753a70fcb5

commit_message:
Move [neutron] auth_url to KeystoneV3Internal

In other sections we already use the internal endpoints for
authentication urls. With this change the auth_uri in the neutron
section gets moved from KeystoneV3Admin to KeystoneV3Internal.

Change-Id: Ia553a60f57bdcd762dc0b92ebd64b91327261815

commit_message:
Grafana: Add pod security context for grafana user

This updates the Grafana chart to include the pod security context
on the grafana pod. This changes the pod's user from root to the
grafana user instead

Change-Id: Id64853640f1941001b83566865defe93227b4291

commit_message:
Use <project>_install_type instead of kolla_install_type

Use <project>_install_type instead of kolla_install_type
to set python_path. For example, general kolla_install_type
is 'binary', but user wants to deploy Horizon from 'source'.
Horizon templates still use python_path=/usr/share/openstack-dashboard,
it is wrong.

Change-Id: Ide6a24e17b1f8ab6506aa5e53f70693706830418

commit_message:
Update generate-gitmodules script for official deliverables

We should generate the list of deliverables from the projects.yaml file
in the governance repo. We should also make the submodule entries
relative rather than absolute so that browsing in other places works.

Also, when adding a git submodule, one needs to use the git submodule
add command. So do that, and trim out old no-longer-existing submodules
too.

Change-Id: I97c812f8497cc32a2ee1b418fce2e6bd20af3bc3

This patch set implements the helm toolkit functionalities to generate a
consistent kubernetes network policy for each chart. This also adds a
chart who shutsdown all the ingress and egress traffics in the namespace
where the chart is deployed. This can be used to ensure the whitelisted
network policy works as intended.

Additionally, implementation is done for some infrastructure chart used
by OpenStack-Helm.

Change-Id: I78e87ef3276e948ae4dd2eb462b4b8012251c8c8

commit_message:
Add network policy toolkit function

This patch set implements the helm toolkit function to generate a
kubernetes network policy manifest based on overrideable values.
This also adds a chart that shuts down all the ingress and egress
traffics in the namespace. This can be used to ensure the
whitelisted network policy works as intended.

Additionally, implementation is done for some infrastructure charts.

Change-Id: I78e87ef3276e948ae4dd2eb462b4b8012251c8c8
Co-Authored-By: Mike Pham <tp6510@att.com>
Signed-off-by: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>

commit_message:
Attempt to read the partition table after writing an image

This patch adds code that tries to read the partition table after we've
successfully written an image to make sure the image that we wrote has a
valid partition table so we can more easily guarantee that what we've
written is bootable and not just junk. Without a valid partition table
writing a config drive will fail for whole disk images.

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Tantsur <dtantsur@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I5cfd8c433a4db3e0d2d5086250e629d16234b7a4
Story: 2001760
Task: 12159

commit_message:
Extend DeployedServerPortMap to include network props

In I68e064d23ec5d43f59146d974cae604d2c5fdb52 we start
using the 'tags' of the ctlplane network via get_attr
on the ControlVirtualIP resource.

Deploted Server need to extend it's DeployedServerPortMap
to provide the network tags.

Change-Id: I1ace0a02e6aa2610559fee0d8576e6f1bc98d699

commit_message:
Ceph: Fix provisioner name substituation typo

This PS fixes a typo in the cephfs provisioner name, which was being given the
same key as rbd to look for.

Change-Id: I84dc541a103fc61feb1998ab41edd602c17e2b6f
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

[{'created': '2019-01-03 17:34:58.000000000', 'message': 'Update heat agent path for image building

The heat-agent dib elements should be pulled from the heat-agents
repository and not the heat-templates repo. These agents have been
recently removed from the heat templates repo which has broken the image
building. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/584777/

commit_message:
Update heat agent path for image building

The heat-agent dib elements should be pulled from the heat-agents
repository and not the heat-templates repo. These agents have been
recently removed from the heat templates repo which has broken the image
building. https://review.openstack.org/#/c/584777/

Change-Id: I5bbf0b7b3c8c69d538f6ad07219a1bdd106a43b1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-12 13:14:39.000000000', 'message': 'Composable Networks - routed subnets (part: 2)

Add parameters for subnets of each network in network_data yaml.
Associate the base subnet of each network with the first segment
of the network. Create additional segments and subnets associated
to the segments.

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I53559ed1445f66fa50508ac9898cbec07914b3fc
'}, {'created': '2018-07-13 07:22:00.000000000', 'message': 'Composable networks - L3 routed networks (2/3)

Add parameters for the subnets of each network in network_data
yaml. Associates the base subnet of each network with the first
segment of the network. (All networks have an implicit first
network segment when they are created.)

Additional segments and subnets defined in the ``subnets`` key
of each composable network is created with subnet to segment
association.

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I53559ed1445f66fa50508ac9898cbec07914b3fc

commit_message:
L3 routed networks - network.j2 (2/3)

Add parameters for the subnets of each network in network_data
yaml. Associates the base subnet of each network with the first
segment of the network. (All networks have an implicit first
network segment when they are created.)

Additional segments and subnets defined in the ``subnets`` key
of each composable network is created with subnet to segment
association.

Partial: blueprint tripleo-routed-networks-templates
Change-Id: I53559ed1445f66fa50508ac9898cbec07914b3fc

subject: L3 routed networks - data + env (1/3)

commit_message:
neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid job inherits from tempest-full-py3

Job neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid was previously converted to
zuulv3 syntax but it inherited from devstack-tempest job.
It's better to inherit from proper job which already have configured
good "tox_envlist" and version of python which should be used.

Change-Id: I686386c48fabebb77813c4284f234f2ee3cb4024
Related-Bug: #1804844

subject: Avoid RPC call on healing a container
messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2019-01-02 02:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23829, 'date': '2019-01-02 03:44:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2019-01-04 03:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-02 02:35:51.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid RPC call on healing a container

In before, we make a RPC call on rebuilding a container on healing,
which is unnecessary. We can directly invoke the container_rebuild
method in the compute manager instead.

Change-Id: Iafafe2f477883234f51c70eb3233ba3053a02087
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid RPC call on healing a container

In before, we make a RPC call on rebuilding a container on healing,
which is unnecessary. We can directly invoke the container_rebuild
method in the compute manager instead.

Change-Id: Iafafe2f477883234f51c70eb3233ba3053a02087

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-03 06:37:46.000000000', 'message': 'Fix AnsibleAction.run() when argument is not a dict

Fix ad hoc commands executed by AnsibleAction.run() when command is not
passed as a dict() but as a normal string, the same way like ordinary
ansible command works.
Check if argument is a dict() and only if it is, use json.dumps() on it.
And not break commands passed as string.

Change-Id: I8b18658bfbae57f264db007e5e81556b0512ef55

(cherry picked from commit 01fb1895a29a6f114045bef231feb6160b65ba80)

commit_message:
Fix AnsibleAction.run() when argument is not a dict

Fix ad hoc commands executed by AnsibleAction.run() when command is not
passed as a dict() but as a normal string, the same way like ordinary
ansible command works.
Check if argument is a dict() and only if it is, use json.dumps() on it.
And not break commands passed as string.

Change-Id: I8b18658bfbae57f264db007e5e81556b0512ef55
Closes-bug: 1805342
(cherry picked from commit 01fb1895a29a6f114045bef231feb6160b65ba80)

commit_message:
Fix AnsibleAction.run() when argument is not a dict

Fix ad hoc commands executed by AnsibleAction.run() when command is not
passed as a dict() but as a normal string, the same way like ordinary
ansible command works.
Check if argument is a dict() and only if it is, use json.dumps() on it.
And not break commands passed as string.

Change-Id: I8b18658bfbae57f264db007e5e81556b0512ef55
Closes-bug: 1805342
(cherry picked from commit 01fb1895a29a6f114045bef231feb6160b65ba80)

[{'created': '2018-11-13 16:20:32.000000000', 'message': "Fix ironic-pxe healthcheck.

When the /run_command file is not found on the
container using the ironic-pxe image, the health
status displays unhealthy even though it's not

commit_message:
Fix ironic-pxe healthcheck.

When the /run_command file is not found on the
container using the ironic-pxe image, the health
status displays unhealthy even though it's not
true. The reason is because grep can't find
the file and the error makes the whole healthcheck
fail.
This patch redirects the error output so the command
doesn't fail, but the conditional is properly
evaluated.

Change-Id: Ia6141f5499f34cd10618378f448598f74aca6273
Closes-Bug: #1803153

[{'created': '2019-01-03 07:47:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fix parse_image_name

Currently, parse_image_name will return
repo = $ipaddr
tag = 5050/ubuntu:latest
when the repo:tag is $ipaddr:5050/ubuntu:latest,
the result is incorrect.

Change-Id: I20b477b3bc52e75e24fe1577ee5f765752ad7775
'}]
commit_message:
Fix parse_image_name

Currently, parse_image_name will return
repo = $ipaddr
tag = 5050/ubuntu:latest
when the repo:tag is $ipaddr:5050/ubuntu:latest,
the result is incorrect.

Change-Id: I20b477b3bc52e75e24fe1577ee5f765752ad7775

- gate-zaqar-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/33/449433/24/check/gate-zaqar-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/cc25785/ : SUCCESS in 3m 21s'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-06-14 21:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

(2 comments)

This seems fine, I guess, I'm just not sure I see the point. Compared to the existing method of doing this (Keystone trusts), this method:

- Posts the service token as well as the user token to Zaqar (in both cases the user token is obtained by posting the service token and a trust ID to keystone.
- Limits services to only posting to queues with names beginning with "service." (but the service _has_ the user's token, and could post to any queue it likes with just that if it were to go rogue).

It would be nice to have a better authorisation model, where the user can choose which queues can be used by which services. And that is (hopefully) coming in OpenStack. As an interim measure this doesn't seem that interesting to me - it's not appreciably more secure and it's not more efficient than trusts.

If I'm misunderstanding then please include a section about how this differs from just using trusts and why it's better.'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2017-06-19 08:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

(2 comments)

@Zane,  thank you for this review.  As I said in reply,  in fact we didn't need the 'user-token' in x-auth-token header.  Searchlight or else will set x-auth-token as same as x-service-token,  and x-project-id is also a service project id.  So compared to using keystone trust,  we don't need to create trust in every user who want to use service queue,  and don't need to let service to know the trust id for getting the user token.  And in security impact,  our way only opens post message API in Zaqar since we just only use the service-token in fact.

I see the description of this spec is still not clear so I will update it to address your concerns."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-06-19 16:21:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2017-06-19 22:35:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2017-06-20 02:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2017-07-25 14:47:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

Let me explain how the trust method would work, because the terminology is a bit confusing:

1) User makes a request to $SERVICE (e.g. Searchlight), asking it to post (some subset of) notifications for a particular project to a given queue.
2) Searchlight uses the user's token, with which they authenticated the request, to create a trust ID with the service user as the trustee and the requesting user as the trustor. (i.e. the requesting user trusts the service to act on their behalf.)
3) When a notification comes in, Searchlight consults its data store for the corresponding project. This will tell it (a) whether the user has requested this notification to be forwarded to a queue, and which one; and (b) the trust ID it can use.
4) Searchlight uses it's own service user credentials + the trust ID to obtain a token that allows it to act on behalf of the user who made the original request to forward the notification to Zaqar.
5) Searchlight uses the token it has obtained, which is scoped to the correct project, to post to the Zaqar queue in the project which corresponds to the notification.

This is the same way that Heat (for e.g. autoscaling operations), Aodh (for sending alarms to Zaqar queues), Zaqar (for sending notifications to e.g. Mistral), and Mistral all use trusts.

Responses to specific objections:

* The notification may not contain a user ID

This is irrelevant. It's the project that you need to know, and the notification _will_ contain that.

* Getting a Keystone token from the trust ID for every notification is expensive.

This is true! Although once you have the token it can be cached for usually 4 hours, so it's not _required_ to fetch a new one for every message. So whether it actually matters in practice depends on the difficulty of implementing that kind of caching in Searchlight. (I'd assume that they'd want to be caching their config anyway, because looking up in the DB whether to post to a queue on every notification would be expensive too.)

In any event, if this is the specific thing that this feature is designed to work around then imho that should be stated explicitly in the spec. Then the Searchlight folks can review and evaluate how important this actually is to them.

* Services implicitly creating trusts is insecure because they can be used for any purpose.

This is also true! But right now it's how OpenStack works; there's no fine-grained authorisation mechanism. Improving this is a top priority:

- https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20170317-cloud-applications-mission.html
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/450415/
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-July/119841.html
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-July/119971.html

At the end of the day though, users have to trust the OpenStack services and there is no way around this.

* Users should create trusts explicitly and then pass them to services

This is dangerously wrong.

It's not actually feasible anyway, because to create a trust you need to know the UUID of the trustee user, and the UUIDs of the service "user"s are not visible to ordinary users. But more importantly, it's really dangerous for the service to accept a trust ID that's passed in by the user - the trust ID is just a number and isn't cryptographically secure (and the security posture is such that, unlike tokens, they e.g. routinely get stored unencrypted, logged, &c.), and the service has no way of knowing that the user generated it legitimately and didn't steal it from somewhere else/just try all of the numbers. To ensure legitimate provenance, the service needs to create the trust ID itself.'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2017-07-31 03:12:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

@Zane, thanks a lot to clarify this !  I see the process with trust method. So I think if we use the trust method, that Zaqar will do not need some changes since Searchlight will use trusted token to post message as same as normal.

But I think it will bring a question that Zaqar can't control the service queue feature on/off since it's hard to adjust by using trustee or trust id from trusted token.

Anyway, I will invite searchlight guys to review this,  see what's their opinions."}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2019-01-04 02:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Improve output of Verify Sphinx build task

Avoid repeated output of HTML content on console and

With python3 these tests fails with below Error:-

'filter' in python3 returns an iterable 'filter'

commit_message:
Wrap output of 'filter' function to a list

With python3 these tests fails with below Error:-

TypeError: 'filter' object is not subscriptable.

'filter' in python3 returns an iterable 'filter'
object, to use it with index need to convert it to list.

Closes-Bug: #1809965
Change-Id: I4ca02849a1c0ca2ea00bc0b86c1c7c452070a770

commit_message:
Remove unused nova packages from host during upgrade and update

As of now, during to upgrade from pike -> queens or doing
minor update on pike/queens deployment, the nova packages upgrade
on compute node changes the permissions on /var/lib/nova tree from
42436 (container nova uid) to 162 (host nova uid) which
prevents user from creating instances with permission Error.

This change handles removing unused nova packages from compute
host during major upgrade as well as minor update on explicitly.

Change-Id: I7e7167252f08f5df555912e0692f33649228fc83
(cherry picked from commit 669a7b8aeb71a3b394c784fa15e137a8edb7b08b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-11 21:45:33.000000000', 'message': "fixed _check_node() in the container sharder

Previously, _check_node() wouldn't catch the raise ValueError when
a drive was unmounted. Therefore the error would bubble up, uncaught,
and stop the shard cycle. The practical effect is that an unmounted
drive on a node would prevent sharding for happening.

This patch updates _check_node() to properly use the check_drive()
method. Furthermore, the _check_node() return value has been modified
to be more similar to what check_drive() actually returns. This
should help prevent similar errors from being introduced in the future.

Closes-Bug: #1806500

Change-Id: I3da9b5b120a5980e77ef5c4dc8fa1697e462ce0d
(cherry picked from commit c26d67efcf44c813034f59b1df78d59fdb4a50e7)
"}]
commit_message:
fixed _check_node() in the container sharder

Previously, _check_node() wouldn't catch the raise ValueError when
a drive was unmounted. Therefore the error would bubble up, uncaught,
and stop the shard cycle. The practical effect is that an unmounted
drive on a node would prevent sharding for happening.

This patch updates _check_node() to properly use the check_drive()
method. Furthermore, the _check_node() return value has been modified
to be more similar to what check_drive() actually returns. This
should help prevent similar errors from being introduced in the future.

Closes-Bug: #1806500

Change-Id: I3da9b5b120a5980e77ef5c4dc8fa1697e462ce0d
(cherry picked from commit c26d67efcf44c813034f59b1df78d59fdb4a50e7)

commit_message:
QNAP: driver should not manage snapshot which does not exist

The snapshot which does not exist in NAS shuold not be managed.

Change-Id: I06475ccc507ee62f3da8f8795694f6da14064036
Closes-Bug: #1810374

commit_message:
Prevent bind fip to port has port forwarding

If one port has port forwarding and the port is under
a dvr router, then binding floating IP to this port
will not be allowed.

Change-Id: Ia014e18264b43cf751a5bc0e82bc55d106582620
Closes-Bug: #1799138

(2 comments)

I did not get how order will be ensured. Also commit message is not relevant to change. It does not look simple and it will be not ordered every time.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2019-01-02 18:31:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Awaiting for response to @PaweÅ Suder's comments."}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-01-03 01:39:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > I did not get how order will be ensured. Also commit message is not
 > relevant to change. It does not look simple and it will be not
 > ordered every time.

Test cases use 'list' or 'tuple' for this servie_plugin param can make sure that the neutron service manger initialize the service plugins in a given-order. How to order this 'list' or 'tuple' should totally base on the 'users' choice, aka child classes. This patch does not order the plugins. And this patch does not ensure that it is ordered. Maybe I should change the commit message to "accept an ordered service_plugin param."'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-01-03 05:12:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-01-03 06:48:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/626538/5 : SUCCESS in 1h 35m 08s'}, {'account_id': 9531, 'date': '2019-01-03 08:22:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-01-03 09:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I'm fine with this change in tests as it will allow to add test cases with some specific order of service plugins and check if all works fine in such cases.

But when I looked at related bug and other patch related to it I'm not sure if we even should require specific order of service plugins. There is anything about that in docs IMO.
So I would like to know opinion of others how to deal with this. Should we make service_plugins list "ordered" like it is with mechanism drivers for example?'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2019-01-03 09:56:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/626538/5 : SUCCESS in 1h 33m 21s'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-01-03 12:26:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Make test service_plugins override simple

Just make things simple and give a chance to accept that
ordered 'service_plugins' list or tuple for the base test
class NeutronDbPluginV2TestCase.

Change-Id: I7c352ede811703e3a96848378b92cbbf5e109228
Related-Bug: #1809238

commit_message:
Add long_description to fix gate

With https://github.com/pypa/twine/commit/125b772 this will not be
necessary, but may as well fix the warning that would get generated.

Apparently this has been broken ever since PTI started using twine, back
in https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/commit/38e40c5

Change-Id: I577883ccc9441cd0eb12eae02149874c736f25a3

commit_message:
cleanup SQLAlchemy required version

Today the requirement for SQLAlchemy has extraneous version specifiers
predating 1.2.0. This patch cleans up the SQLAlchemy version specifiers
in requirements.txt.

Change-Id: I9ddef79d91dba662fef58bc8ee8c0face9f0fab2

There appears to be other uses that could be changed [1]. Is the intent here just address the single use herein, or should we also take care of the others [1]?


[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=rule%3Aadmin_only&i=nope&files=&repos=neutron'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2019-01-03 14:22:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> There appears to be other uses that could be changed [1]. Is the
 > intent here just address the single use herein, or should we also
 > take care of the others [1]?
 > 
 > 
 > [1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=rule%3Aadmin_only&i=nope&files=&repos=neutron

Those other uses are not the same. This is only use in definition of policy in code and I just wanted to make it consistent with all other places as this was introduced "in parallel" with change which changed all other places in neutron/conf/policies.
I think that if we want to change it in other places, it should be done in separate patch IMHO'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2019-01-03 15:10:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
consume get_updatable_fields from neutron-lib

The neutron.objects.base.get_updatable_fields function is now in
neutron-lib. This patch consumes it by removing the function from
neutron and using lib's version instead.

NeutronLibImpact

Change-Id: Ia06ad97e053dd59a1163f6c31199dde07bb0ffbf

commit_message:
Migrate neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid job to zuulv3 and python 3

This patch also removes config of osprofiler middleware in api-paste.ini
file in neutron-tempest-iptables_hybrid job as this middleware is
currently enabled by default.

Change-Id: Ifd3fdc33ba5c489618a568cccc20ee14e7d600a6

commit_message:
Update test_trunk after adding new ip command tool.

A new tool has been added to wrap with ip command
line tool.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/613310/

This tool implements methods to list VM adrresses
and to configure VLAN device interfaces via an
SSH connection.

This refactor trunk test case to improve code
readability and make this test to use shared code
base with other test cases to be written in the
future related with trunk related scenarios.

Change-Id: I61563b7132f9911ad588d35f7f01125ef4c70cd2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-07 18:49:40.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Use os-resource-classes in placement

os-resource-classes is a pending python library in which the
standardized resource classes will be maintained. It is done as a
library so that multiple services (e.g., placement and nova) can use the
same stuff.

It is used and managed here in the same way the os-traits library is
used: At system start up we compare the contents of the resource_classes
table with the classes in the library and add any that are missing.
CUSTOM resource classes are added with a high id (and always were, even
before this change).

The resource_class_cache of id to string and string to id mappings
continues to maintained, but now it looks solely in the database.
As part of confirming that code, it was discovered that the reader
context manager was being entered twice, this has been fixed.

Similarly, while updating the database fixture to ensure that the
resource classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup
was being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

The os-resource-classes library has not fully migrated to openstack
infra yet, nor has it been published to pypi, so it is added as a
special requirement in tox.ini. It can't be in requirements.txt yet
because though pip can install a git reference from requirements.txt,
when usedevelop is True in tox, pbr and setuptools get involved, and
they don't understand git references. Once the library is released, it
can be listed in requirements.txt as plain package.

Because os-resource-classes is in transition, it currently doesn't have
all the standard resource classes that were in the now deleted
rc_fields. Once it lands we can update it to have the correct contents.
This lack is the cause of the 3 failing functional tests.

Also, it names the STANDARD resource classes as ORDERED_CLASSES which
originally seemed like a good idea when done in isolation, but turns out
not be a great idea. So when os-resource-classes lands, we should change
that, and change this code as well.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changes to a
StringField. The definition was in rc_field and we simply don't need it
anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation on
the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe

have all the standard resource classes that were in the now deleted
rc_fields. The depends-on below is to the patch that adds the fields.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'osc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/624370
Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe
"}, {'created': '2018-12-13 12:24:14.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Use os-resource-classes in placement

os-resource-classes is a pending python library in which the
standardized resource classes will be maintained. It is done as a
library so that multiple services (e.g., placement and nova) can use the
same stuff.

It is used and managed here in the same way the os-traits library is
used: At system start up we compare the contents of the resource_classes
table with the classes in the library and add any that are missing.
CUSTOM resource classes are added with a high id (and always were, even
before this change).

The resource_class_cache of id to string and string to id mappings
continues to be maintained, but now it looks solely in the database.
As part of confirming that code, it was discovered that the reader
context manager was being entered twice, this has been fixed.

Similarly, while updating the database fixture to ensure that the
resource classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup
was being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

The os-resource-classes library has not yet been published to pypi, so
it is added as a special requirement in tox.ini. It can't be in
requirements.txt yet because though pip can install a git reference from
requirements.txt, when usedevelop is True in tox, pbr and setuptools get
involved, and they don't understand git references. Once the library is
released, it can be listed in requirements.txt as a plain package.

Because os-resource-classes is in transition, master currently doesn't
have all the standard resource classes that were in the now deleted
rc_fields. The depends-on below is to the patch that adds the fields.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'osc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/624370
Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe

"}, {'created': '2018-12-17 09:40:54.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Use os-resource-classes in placement

(Something very odd happening in the perfload job, is either bad sql or
threading.)

os-resource-classes is a python library in which the standardized
resource classes are maintained. It is done as a library so that
multiple services (e.g., placement and nova) can use the same stuff.

It is used and managed here in the same way the os-traits library is
used: At system start up we compare the contents of the resource_classes
table with the classes in the library and add any that are missing.
CUSTOM resource classes are added with a high id (and always were, even
before this change). We need to insert standard resource classes
with an id of zero, so we need to protect against mysql thinking 0
on a primary key id is "generate the next one".

The resource_class_cache of id to string and string to id mappings
continues to be maintained, but now it looks solely in the database.
As part of confirming that code, it was discovered that the reader
context manager was being entered twice, this has been fixed.

Similarly, while updating the database fixture to ensure that the
resource classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup
was being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'orc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

'}, {'created': '2018-12-17 11:30:45.000000000', 'message': 'Use os-resource-classes in placement

os-resource-classes is a python library in which the standardized
resource classes are maintained. It is done as a library so that
multiple services (e.g., placement and nova) can use the same stuff.

It is used and managed here in the same way the os-traits library is
used: At system start up we compare the contents of the
resource_classes table with the classes in the library and add any
that are missing. CUSTOM resource classes are added with a high id
(and always were, even before this change). Because we need to
insert standard resource classes with an id of zero, so we need to
protect against mysql thinking 0 on a primary key id is "generate
the next one". We don't need a similar thing in os-traits because
we don't care about the ids there. And we don't need to guard
against postgresql or sqlite at this point because they do not have
the same behavior.

The resource_class_cache of id to string and string to id mappings
continues to be maintained, but now it looks solely in the database.
As part of confirming that code, it was discovered that the reader
context manager was being entered twice, this has been fixed.

Locking around every access to the resource class cache is fairly
expensive (changes the perfload job from <2s to >5s). Prior to this
change we would only go to cache if the resource classes in the
query were not standards. Now we always look at the cache so rather
than locking around reads and writes we only lock around writes.
This should be okay, because as long as we do a get (intead of the
previous two separate accesses) on the cache's dict that operation
is safe and if it misses (because something else destroyed the
cache) the fall through is to refresh the cache, which still has the
lock.

While updating the database fixture to ensure that the resource
classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup was
being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'orc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe

lock.

While updating the database fixture to ensure that the resource
classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup was
being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'orc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe
'}]
commit_message:
Use os-resource-classes in placement

os-resource-classes is a python library in which the standardized
resource classes are maintained. It is done as a library so that
multiple services (e.g., placement and nova) can use the same stuff.

It is used and managed here in the same way the os-traits library is
used: At system start up we compare the contents of the
resource_classes table with the classes in the library and add any
that are missing. CUSTOM resource classes are added with a high id
(and always were, even before this change). Because we need to
insert standard resource classes with an id of zero, so we need to
protect against mysql thinking 0 on a primary key id is "generate
the next one". We don't need a similar thing in os-traits because
we don't care about the ids there. And we don't need to guard
against postgresql or sqlite at this point because they do not have
the same behavior.

The resource_class_cache of id to string and string to id mappings
continues to be maintained, but now it looks solely in the database.
As part of confirming that code, it was discovered that the reader
context manager was being entered twice, this has been fixed.

Locking around every access to the resource class cache is fairly
expensive (changes the perfload job from <2s to >5s). Prior to this
change we would only go to cache if the resource classes in the
query were not standards. Now we always look at the cache so rather
than locking around reads and writes we only lock around writes.
This should be okay, because as long as we do a get (intead of the
previous two separate accesses) on the cache's dict that operation
is safe and if it misses (because something else destroyed the
cache) the fall through is to refresh the cache, which still has the
lock.

While updating the database fixture to ensure that the resource
classes are synched properly, it was discovered that addCleanup was
being called twice with the same args. That has been fixed.

In objects/resource_provider.py the ResourceClass field is changed to a
StringField. The field definition was in rc_field and we simply don't
need it anymore. This is satisfactory because we don't do any validation
on the field internal to the objects (but do elsewhere).

Based on initial feedback, 'os_resource_classes' is imported as 'orc'
throughout to avoid unwieldy length.

Change-Id: Ib7e8081519c3b310cd526284db28c623c8410fbe
